Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 04:30PM ccarter48818 wrote: I am in Michigan and have had bad experiences with 3 different facilities here.  Granted 2 were small town hospitals that were satellites of the bigger Sparrow Hospital in Lansing and Lacks Cancer Center in Grand Rapids, and then Spectram Health of Grand Rapids.  There were so many things that were done wrong, missed, reports never given to me in timely fashion.  And the last straw when I ended up in Butterworth Hospital in terrible shape and no one could figure out what was wrong with me.  I had sky high blood pressure, nausea, horrible headache.  What I got was a drug-induced seizure and an MRI that showed I didn't have brain mets.  Any finally was sent home with another blood pressure med to try and keep my blood pressure under control.  Since that visit, I had PET/CT scan that showed my bone mets were active all over the place and many liver mets in both lobes; previously I had never had liver mets.  That last hospital stay was the straw that broke the camel's back.  I've slipped into a serious depression and moved my treatment to one of he top cancer centers in the country, University of Michigan Cancer Center. I've been there for 3 treatments now and I am amazed at the competency and how comprehensive they are.  My cancer seems to under control for now, but the depression has gotten very serious and locally I'm not getting the help I need.  I saw a therapist yesterday and she told me that honestly if I were her sister she would tell me to get my mental health care also at U of M where they are trained to treat and council patients dealing with my special needs.   My husband called today and they are setting me up immediately with help.  I can't believe what more than 3 1/2 years of the trauma, mistakes and incompetence of the medical communities I've had to deal with.  I was only a couple of days out of the hospital back in July and that morning I felt the light and hope go out of me.  I'm no longer living...I'm just existing. I haven't always felt this way since my diagnosis.  I used to have hope, I used to laugh, I used to enjoy my family but now I have none of that.  I don't even know if they can help me at U of M. But knowing what I know now, I would NEVER go anywhere except one of the 10 top rated cancer centers in the country.  I checked out CTC and BCBS would cover all but 20%, afraid we could never pay that much out of pocket. Lydia is in Michigan, and I so hope she calls U of M for help. Carla
Posts.Title: What are your real thoughts on CTCA LuAnnH Alpal

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 04:39PM ccarter48818 wrote: We pay nothing out of pocket.  My husband has a Health Savings Account where his employer puts in $2500.00 and we use that up and then our insurance pays everything else.  We have BCBS of Michigan.  Of course, the year is almost up and with sky premiums who knows what our contract will be like come January 1. Carla
Posts.Title: What are your real thoughts on CTCA LuAnnH Alpal

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 12:44PM ccarter48818 wrote: Janis, When I started chemo this past January, waited until just after the holidays, doctor said that was OK, my nurse started to hang the chemo bags and I asked her at what weight my dosage was calcualted at.  She checked it and said I was 138, I told her no, I was down to 115 lbs.  She never checked my weight, my temperature, my blood pressure nothing.  This was common throughout my treatments.  The weight was far enough off that the chemo calculations had to be redone.  I can only imagine how ill I might have become had they given me the higher dose.  Nothing was ever double checked.  At U of M everything is checked at least twice.  They have 2 pharmacists verify each patients meds, and in front of me 2 nurses have to check the doses and ask my name and date of birth before I receive any treatment. My doctor out of G.R. Lack's was never on the same page as the staff.  He would order something scheduled and staff was supposed to call that day and nothing, over and over again.  If I didn't have my scan reports faxed to me directly I wouldn't hear about what was on them for weeks.  When I was in the hospital back in July rather than my doctor telling me he really didn't know what happened and only scheduling a brain MRI, he should have scheduled a PET/CT and not have waited a month or so to do it. I'm glad for you Janis that your experiences have been better, but if things ever do feel like they're not quite right don't wait as long as I did.  Not only have I suffered significant progression, but now I am going to have to fight my way back from depression and anxiety.  All I think now, is what's the point; I'm going to die anyway; why even try.   Carla
Posts.Title: What are your real thoughts on CTCA LuAnnH Alpal

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 08:43PM ccarter48818 wrote: We sued my 2 doctors, and the radiologist for negligence.  I was misdiagnosed for more than a year when the breast cancer was plainly there from my first mammogram.  The radiologist even admitted that she screwed up in her deposition.  Because of the delay I wasn't diagnosed until I had extensive bone mets and several vertebra fractures.  We settled out of court because if you know anything about Michigan malpractice laws they are made to favor the insurance companies and the doctors.  If we had not taken a cash settlement and chose to go to trial there would have been a good chance that if a jury ruled in our favor the attornies for the doctors/insurance companies would appeal and keep the whole thing tied up in court for years.  There are also very low caps on what you can get as far any financial damages.  Had our case not been so blatantly negligent we probably would have received nothing and as it was we got enough to pay off some of our debt and some to put away for emergencies.  I have seen in other states cases exactly like mine where the awards have been in the millions.  So much for laws that are supposed to prevent frivalous lawsuits; these laws keep the one's who  actually were hurt from receiving any kind of justice.  And to add insult to injury the doctors who wronged me were never investigated because they kept the financial amount we received below the amount that would have required the doctors be invesitgated and we were required to sign a gag order.  I got life, they continue to live rich in their new homes and  expensive cars. Carla
Posts.Title: What are your real thoughts on CTCA LuAnnH Alpal

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 01:33PM ccarter48818 wrote: You are not an idiot!  It's Cancer Treatment Centers of America.  There are several in the US, do a google and you'll find them. Kindly, Carla
Posts.Title: What are your real thoughts on CTCA LuAnnH Alpal

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 08:16PM ccarter48818 wrote: Jennifer, I think it's definitely worth the trip and I really do hate the 2 1/2 hour drive.  I have been screwed over so many times and lost any confidence I did have in the medical community over the last 3 1/2 years.  I'm sure hoping not only can they give me the best possible chance at a longer life, but also someone to bring back my sanity, and some sense of peace.  I'm afraid I've been considering the "dying would be better than this" option a little  too much lately.  But I know I don't really want to die; I just want to feel like living again. Kindly, Carla
Posts.Title: What are your real thoughts on CTCA LuAnnH Alpal

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 08:32AM ccarter48818 wrote: I just can't believe this; rest peacefully dear Lydia.  My hearfelt sympathies to her family. Carla
Posts.Title: Luv2Travel is an Angel now LuAnnH BonnieVA

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 03:03AM ccarter48818 wrote: I am going so far as to saying I'm almost certain my cancer was caused by stress. Ten years before my diagnosis I suffered severe post partum depression after my last child was born.  It was a horrendous situation and I thought I was losing my mind.  I had another episode of it a year later and have suffered with anxiety and depression in different degrees from then on. Two years before my diagnosis my mother died at 63 years old and my sister and who I had been close in age and heart my entire life had a huge falling out. I suffered terribly and believe me I made sure we mended that fence when I was diagnosed.  I knew I needed some emotional peace.   I don't think I have ever really handled stress well; always making things a bigger issue than they really are.  Always the over thinker and the worrier to the point of making myself a wreck.   I was misdiagnosed for over a year and my mammograms/ultrsounds showed such an explosion of the cancer over those months of stress.  I just know in my heart that my inability to control and process stress was a huge factor in my illness.   I does seem cruel though to think stress may cause such a horrible disease when the disease alone causes so much stress of it's own.
Posts.Title: Has cancer pshycological roots? vivo bygracealone

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2009 05:51PM ccarter48818 wrote: Brenda; big Congrats!  My oldest son (of 4) was married this past April; one of the happiest day's of my life.  My daughter-in-law's family is also very Republican and somewhat religious, while we are not religious and very liberal.  I just always make it a point to keep my mouth shut when her Uncle and Grandmother start spouting what to me are very inflammatory rants.  For me very hard to do, but my daughter-in-law is not like that at all.  Would have never worked with my son; believe you me! I wouldn't be surprised if my next oldest son gets engaged this Christmas.  They have been together for 6 years.  Jen was only 14 and Chris 18 when they started seeing each other and she has wanted a ring for at least 5 of those years!  Chris graduated this past May from college and has a very good job so she's definitely ready for that ring. I'm hoping for a grandchild or 2 before too many years and hoping I'm here and feeling good.  I guess none of us know for sure how long we have on this earth but before BC I didn't think twice about planning for the future.  Now I even think twice before renewing my magazine subscriptions, but I do it anyway! Also my husband and I helped with some of the cost, but since my daughter-in-law and her Mom had been planning this shindig since she was a little girl I didn't have to do anything.  It was all catered and at a beautiful country club which made everything so much more stress free. Carla
Posts.Title: Youngest son got engaged! Analemma RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 08:47PM ccarter48818 wrote: Hi Diane, I'm feeling a bit better about all of it now.  My onc. (new one, very unhappy with my previous) is a good compassionate man and he went through my PET/CT and told me we can get this under control.  I will start oral Xeloda as soon as we can get it and he says we will monitor very closely for my response.  He says he wants to waste no time on a treatment that isn't producing good results relatively quickly.  He also was very adamant that if when I start the treatment and the side-effects should be too much that I am to stop immediately, call him, and he will adjust the dosage.   I'm so glad you also have no liver mets; that seemed to be the one saving grace for me in all of this.  Isn't it funny that no matter how bad it seems sometimes we can usually find something positive?  Maybe that's just human nature's way of self-soothing...that and talking with such wonderful compassionate people such as yourself and the other ladies on this board.
Posts.Title: CT/PET So Much Progression ccarter48818 ccarter48818

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 08:52PM ccarter48818 wrote: Hi Janis, Your presence here has always been comforting to me.  You were here when I first joined and have always been so encouring and caring; thank you so much. Yes, I'm ready to go on fighting.  I think shell-shocked is what happens when you get these kind of scan results and then you have to re-group and get it together again.   Hope you are feeling well and enjoying those cute boys of yours. Hugs, Carla

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2007 09:11PM ccarter48818 wrote: Robin, It is so good to hear that you haven't had problems with Xeloda; I'm so hoping that will be the case for me too.  I'm grateful that things have changed from the way chemo was done years ago.  My nurse told me that it used to dosed as a "one size fits all" I can't even imagine how awful that would be. Thanks so much for the encouragement and information. Hugs, Carla Crystal, MI

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2007 09:08PM ccarter48818 wrote: Hi Kasey, My doctor is having my prescription of Xeloda shipped to me and it should be here on Monday.  Something about the pharmacies in our area don't keep it on hand and some even take a long time to get it when they order it.   Not sure what the dose is yet, but I know he was figuring it by my height and weight.  He made a point of telling me if I had any bad side-effects that I was to stop the meds immediately and call him so the dose could be adjusted.   I'm still trying to adjust to the news of this progression, but am ready to start getting this crappy stuff back under control.  My poor family is having quite a time dealing with it too; so the sooner we get some good news the better. I'm so glad you are having good results with your current round of chemo and sending you wishes for continued success. Thank you so much for posting to me. Hugs, Carla

Carla
Posts.Title: Heart Racing/Shortness of Breath stayingstrong Alpal

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2009 05:03PM ccarter48818 wrote: Well, had my liver biopsy last Thursday, and thankfully it was a breeze.  No pain during the procedure and just a little tenderness in the area for a couple of days.  The pathology report says the liver mets are still estrogen/progesterone positive, and her2 negative.  I'm glad I had it done, otherwise would have drove me crazy wondering. I also had my first chemo round of AC, but found out my doctor had changed the "A" to a similar drug that was supposed to be a bit less toxic to the heart.  Didn't think about it at the time, but later it made me wonder if something had showed on my MUGA to make him go with the other drug.  I've had no side-effects with the chemo, that I can tell are new anyway, already was having bone pain so pain isn't new.  No nausea or vomitting so that's all good. My appointment with University of Michigan has been scheduled for Tuesday, so am relieved to be finding out their take on my condition.  The woman from U of M told me the only one's she had problems getting my medical records from was my oncologist's office; no surprise there.  That office never seems to do anything in a timely manner; hence my reason for deciding to go to a major leading cancer center.   I had something happen yesterday that broke my heart and I'm still upset and crying about today. My son works for CMU's football team and since the weather was nice my husband and I decided that maybe I was strong enough to go to the game.  The last few months have really knocked the strength out of me so have been laying low at home most of the time.   Well nearing the end of the game I told my husband I was going to head up to the main level and use the bathroom and wait for him up there until the game finished.  Big underestimation of how weak I am.  Because we were low in the stadium I had to take steps UP with no side railings and no seat backs to support or steady myself.  I took 6 or 7 steps up and got very tired so had to sit in one of the vacant seats for a minute and then started up again.  With my balance off and my strength gone I staggered some and had to be helped by a couple of people.  I thought that with my hat it would have been obvious that I was an "ill" person not a "drunk" person.  But once I got to the platform there were comments from some people about "thought that kind of stuff was just for the young kids here" and "thought I could smell alcohol"!  I couldn't believe that there were some people that instead of thinking I was ill thought I had been drinking.  I stood there for a couple of minutes stunned and then went into the bathroom and broke down sobbing.  I can't believe how much that hurt; don't know why I let such ignorance from strangers get to me, but it did. My husband and sons were furious when I told them.  Course my husband was also upset for letting me take the stairs alone.   Guess that's my "worst thing anyone has ever said to you" since being diagnosed.   Hugs, Carla Crystal, MI
Posts.Title: Crap Liver Mets ccarter48818 sportsmom

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2009 11:20PM ccarter48818 wrote: Thanks so much Darlene.  I hadn't even thought about the possibility that we could get a liver biospy.  I know what you mean about her2 positive being a good thing and a bad thing.  It does seem that Herceptin and Tykerb many times are miracle drugs and seem to keep you positive ladies stable for a long time.  My mind is swimming with all the uncertainties at the moment.  I'll be glad for Monday when I can hopefully get something happening as far as what to do next. Thank you again Darlene.  I'll be posting when I find out more. Hugs, Carla
Posts.Title: Crap Liver Mets ccarter48818 sportsmom

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 12:19AM ccarter48818 wrote: Donna, I was on Taxol/Avastin from January of this year until June.  What happened to you is so frightening; I'm assuming you had an allergic reaction?  These kinds of things happening are exactly what has caused me to have post traumatic stress and severe depression.  Thankfully, I am a few weeks into taking Zoloft again and it is at least making it so I can function again.   When I talked to my nurse this week about having a liver biopsy being scheduled to check my her2 status she asked me what it was when I was diagnosed 3 1/2 years ago and when I told her it was negative; she said; well than it's still the same.  She didn't buy it when I told her I had read of other women's her2 status as changing sometimes depending on where the mets are.   I hate that I get dismissed so often with my nurses but with my doctor also.  Months ago I brought up the new treatment of using estrogen to try and shrink tumors and then when that fails trying anti-hormonals to see if the receptors were again hormonally sensitive.  He just kind of smiled and told me to bring in the studies that showed this research.   I have had so many bad incidents that I have a very hard time believing anything any doctor tells me.
Posts.Title: Crap Liver Mets ccarter48818 sportsmom

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 08:42PM ccarter48818 wrote: Hi Kirby, My liver biopsy is finally scheduled for tomorrow.   It was supposed to be scheduled ASAP but it appears no one requested the PET/CT disk from Michigan State, so took more than a week and a half just to get the procedure scheduled.  Crazy, as I had the disk in my hand within 20 minutes after my scan and the report in less than 24 hours.  My doctor wanted me to have started A/C chemo yesterday so that has been put off until next Tuesday.  In the meantime, I'm just trying to keep my bone mets pain under control.  Will need to be up at 4:00 a.m tomorrow to be at the hospital by 6:00.  I sure hope this biopsy goes off without a hitch. Carla

Posts.Content: May 20, 2009 06:45PM ccarter48818 wrote: I have terrible survivor's guilt right now.  I just got an NED on my scans; been on Taxol/Avastin since Jan 6 of this year.  The Mom of my daughter-in-law of one month is in hospice care.  She was diagnosed just 3 months ago with stage 4 lung cancer; she is 51.  Nothing has gone right for her and now it's just a matter of days it looks like.  The wedding was moved up as soon as they found out her diagnosis from July 25 to April 18.  Thank goodness it was moved up and she was able to see her only child married.  I just can't feel happy right now; maybe relieved I guess. Hugs, Carla

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 09:11PM ccarter48818 wrote: Hi Kim; I'm feeling down too.  I have scans tomorrow morning.  First since starting Taxol/Avastin in January.  Have been doing BC stage 4 from the get go for 3 years now and I still have my falling apart and desperate depression days.  Can't seem to pull myself out of it right now either. I know it passes, but it's sure hell when it's upon us.   I also have a 13-year-old boy (and a 26 yo boy, & 23 yo boy, and 21 yo boy)  I've had extensive bone mets that have bounced in and out of NED for the 3 years and had 5 lung mets once that disappeared after Xeloda and haven't been back since.Hoping they are still gone, but the scans tomorrow are definitely causing me scanxiety. Its sounds like your scans are very good!  I think I should always be up and positive all the time too, but it's just not possible.  Fears, hormones, meds, and just everyday life make it too hard to be cheery every day. You're right about just wanting to be here a long time!  Usually that is where my thoughts go on my down days.  On those days I can't see a future, but when I'm back to my "normal" the future is still there; right along with the hope I was lacking at the moment!  Here's to a better day tomorrow dear Kim. Hugs, Carla

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 11:19PM ccarter48818 wrote: Thanks to all of you for your replies.  I served jury duty in the 90s and it wasn't a big deal, but I did have to be there for 2 full days in a row and I know there's no way I can do that.  The letter is kind of upsetting threatening contempt of court for not filling out the questionanaire.   I had to go through several pages to find the phone number of the court; it wasn't even put in the letter heading.   I'll call tomorrow and tell them my circumstances and find out what they need for verification if any.   I know I overreacted to this, but it just seems like another thing to have to deal with when I can't deal as it is.  My damn dentist's office called TWICE in 4 days wanting me to schedule my cleaning!  I don't even answer the phone most of the time anymore. Thanks again. Carla Crystal, MI

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 08:12PM ccarter48818 wrote: Hi Elizabeth, You are so right that those who have not suffered from real clinical depression have no idea how really awful it is. I had post partum depression 14 years ago after my youngest was born.  I had no idea what was happening to me; thought I was losing my mind and I would never be the person I was before.  I recovered from that and had another episode a year later, so I'm definitely not a complete stranger to what it's like.  I had actually been quite amazed that I had gotten through a lot of trauma with my cancer diagnosis without falling into a major episode and then "whoops" spoke to soon. I even remember the day it started; went to sit on the couch one morning shortly after that hospital visit and it was like the lights went out.  It's been like that and getting worse. I definitely think the Effexor is way too low.  My thyroid levels have been very low so he is also trying to work on those too and my last test showed I was now getting too much synthroid.   I did something I probably shouldn't have tonight because narcotics scare the crap out of me, but I took two Vicadin because it lifts my mood enough that I can stop crying and actually think rationally. I have oxycontin too, but I don't touch that only for severe pain.  I'm not an addictive personality, but that stuff is so powerful for not only pain, but for making life seem perfect.  Downside is that it can have the opposite effect when getting off it. I know narcotic drug addiction is not the answer. Thanks so much for writing to me Elizabeth.  I know we are all struggling so it means so much to me when the wonderful women on this board still offer up hope and support.  You made me feel better and not alone. Big hugs to you, Carla
Posts.Title: Clinical Depression ccarter48818 konakat

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 08:27PM ccarter48818 wrote: 33skidoo; thank you I can get those books at my library.  I have wondered myself about the meds, whether they were the right ones.  I also had just started my new chemo regimen of Epirubicin/Cytoxan after the liver mets diagnosis.  I'm sure all of this started my down hill slide. The chemo has really been kicking my butt physically too.  I have to give myself a neulasta shot the next day after the chemo and just this past Saturday had to have a blood transfusion.  I've also been getting the shot that's supposed to raise the red cells, but hasn't been doing enough.  It's knocking my tumor markers down and I'm supposed to get 2 or 3 more treatments and then try an anti-hormonal.   I'm so glad that I can count you as one that has been through this hell and is around to say she recovered from it.  Gives me much more hope. Hugs, Carla
Posts.Title: Clinical Depression ccarter48818 konakat

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2009 07:17PM ccarter48818 wrote: Dear Helen, Please don't wait as long as I have to get treatment.  I started having problems back in July and if I had gotten help sooner I wouldn't be in the shape I am now and having to struggle back.  I have also with this depression thought about dying, but I can tell you that for most of my stage 4 diagnosis, more than 3 1/2 years, I was not depressed.  Those obsessive thoughts take on a life of their own when you're depressed and having had them myself with post-partum depression I can say they can be helped with medication.  Like all the advice I have been given, run don't walk to get the help you need. You may be one that responds very quickly to anti-depressants and won't have to wait as long as I have been for relief.  You like me have a lot to live for.  My family when I expressed how badly I felt making them suffer just told me not to worry about them, they just want ME to feel better. Let yourself be taken care of so you can start feeling better soon.  We can both be on the road to recovery together. You will have other options with your treatment too; so there is a good chance you won't have the bad side effects you had with the other regimen.  Plus there is so much more that can be done to make you feel better while going through treatment. Hugs, Carla
Posts.Title: Clinical Depression ccarter48818 konakat

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 09:05PM ccarter48818 wrote:  Dear Fidelia, Thank you so much; your experience with this nasty, rotten disease gives me hope of living and coping with its up and downs.  Just wishing for a few more "ups" than "downs"  The depression has done exactly what none of us need; the cancer has become the only thing I can think about.  I know this isn't normal even for me.  Since I was diagnosed I do feel like there is a dark shadow over me, but I had been able to ignore it enough to still enjoy my life. I am used to doing for everybody, like with the holidays coming up I usually do a lot of cooking.  I know at least for Thanksgiving that's not going to be the case.  It's stupid because I feel guilty about not being able to do the things I once did.  You are right; we as women need to give ourselves a break; especially when dealing with an illness.   I've always been pretty hard on myself in thinking I never do enough, or what I do isn't good enough.  I know that can set you right up for getting depressed.   Thanks so much for your advice; it makes a world of difference. Hugs, Carla
Posts.Title: Clinical Depression ccarter48818 konakat

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 09:17PM ccarter48818 wrote: Dear Anallema, The worst part of this depression is the trial and error of trying to find the right drug and the waiting for it to make a difference.  The waiting is excruciating.   I think the Effexor is too low too and since I had been on it before and still got depressed, I don't think it's the right one for me.  It does help with the hotflashes though.   Elavil is what I took years ago and it worked.  Doctors don't seem to want to prescribe it much anymore though.  I'm going to ask about Celexa; it seems like there are quite a few on the boards that take it.   Thanks so much for writing to me.  Three of my boys are in their 20s and one is married.  I have only one at home and he is 14.  Hugs, Carla

Posts.Title: New plan of action anitach rkt

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 10:20PM ccarter48818 wrote: Janis I've been getting this test since last year at the Lack's Cancer Cener in G.R.  It's very relevent in predicting progression for me as my tumor markers have always been normal.   After I started Xeloda last fall my Cell Search test came back at 0 then 1 and then 0 again.  I started having leg and hip pain in July and the Cell Search came back at 8 and my most recent one was 60 something.  I recently had a CT/Bone scan and had lots of bone mets progression.    I really like this test as it appears to give a good indication if my treatment is working.  Hopefully, after I get the Faslodex going good my next Cell Search number will be back to 0. Carla Crystal, MI

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 05:08PM ccarter48818 wrote: Janis, what a great post.  I have 4 sons and you gave fantastic insight and advice.  My older boys, (men) actually are 26, 23, & 22, but I also have  a 14 year-old who was only 10 when I was diagnosed.  I feel so guilty  that he has not had the "normal" childhood that his older brothers had.  He has seen my fear and meltdowns on a pretty regular basis for the last 3 1/2 years.  I know he is afraid for me but he expresses his emotions with anger and disrespect towards me, especially when he hit that 13 puberty age.  Problems, problems, they are always there. Carla
